work.p: The first sentence of this manuscript is very similar to a line that appears in the poem later titled "Song of Myself." The manuscript line reads "truly the things commonest & cheapest, nearest to us of our daily lives are often the profoundest, the most curious things." The line from the poem, as it appears in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, reads "What is commonest and cheapest and nearest and easiest is Me."

notesStmt.note: The first sentence of this manuscript is very similar to a line that appears in the poem later titled "Song of Myself." The line from the poem, as it appears in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, reads "What is commonest and cheapest and nearest and easiest is Me." The date of the manuscript is therefore probably before or early in 1855. Edward Grier notes that the handwriting and the use of small scraps of paper also suggest an early date (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 5:1622).

bibl.note: On the back of the first leaf is a crossed-out section of prose, words from which may have been used in "Starting from Paumanok" (1860). On the backs of the second and third leaves (which probably originally formed one sheet of paper that has been torn apart) are three sections that constitute a plan for Democratic Vistas, probably written in the mid- to late-1860s.
Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.p:
It is indeed truly that the what is things commonest & cheapest, nearest a plenteous often what is things nearest to us of all our whole daily daily lives,—is are often the profoundest, the most curious things—dates—have their beginnings the farthest back, & carry the most with them & is are worthiest of thought, notice study notice, science.
So reader dear if I can catch thy attention, have at thee! reader!
And then the satisfaction, the fitness, the pleasure, the sanity, the growth and upward & the mellowing and vigor & expansion of such study!
? for conclusion. Hast thou never thought (if not true absolutely it is least worth suggesting) that how how there are
certain trains nutriments of studyies & researches (not college courses, or technisms) almost as necessary for thee, for thy body & soul, as thy food, as good air, as human association and friendship?—and that this very one of Names (Language), is of them?
And tThen too the satisfaction, the ease, the pleasure, the sanity, the growth upward, and the mellowing vigor, expansion, (I say the democracy) of much study!

Not to be taken up as an ungracious duty for school hours, or conned by rote from boo text books, or, even reported learned from the lectures of the professors—or —not to be got through with in the crude seasons of youth or early manhood or womanhood, & then laid aside. But taken leisurely—no haste—always eligible—fed by all days, times, all occasions—truly a sane & exhilarating pursuit, for l that can be made active
or passive, quietly adapting itself to all opportunities, for all the phases & all phases, & stages of Life!
